## Definition

Let $S$ be a [numerical semigroup](../Basic-concepts/Numerical-semigroup.qmd) [minimally generated](../Basic-concepts/Minimal-set-of-generators.qmd) by $B = \{n_1, \ldots, n_e\}$ with $n_1 < n_2 < \cdots < n_e$. For each $i \in \{2, \ldots, e\}$, set

$$
c_i = \min \{k \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0\} ~ | ~ kn_i \in \langle B \setminus \{n_i\} \rangle\}.
$$

It is said that $S$ is simple if $n_1 = (c_2 - 1) + \cdots + (c_e - 1)$.

## Examples

$\circ$ Let $S = \langle 4, 5, 7 \rangle$. Then, $5, 10 \not \in \langle 4, 7 \rangle$ and $15 = 2 \cdot 4 + 7 \in \langle 4, 7 \rangle$, so $c_2 = 3$. On the other hand, $7 \not \in \langle 4, 5 \rangle$ but $14 = 4 + 2 \cdot 5 \in \langle 4, 5 \rangle$, therefore $c_3 = 2$. Finally, $(c_2-1) + (c_3 - 1) = 3 \ne 4$ and $S$ is not simple.
